item.title: [OVR_multiview2] WebXR guide material tracking issue
item.content:encoded:
(updated given Dominic's comment and more own thoughts)

Filing this bug to collect what kind of guide/tutorial content is missing in the WebXR docs. Planning to share this with subject matter experts and hopefully get some help with completing these pages

Landing pages

  • Brush up the MDN graphics landing page to be more useful and to talk about WebXR
  • Organize the WebXR Device API landing page better (list the interfaces more efficiently, put more focus on the tutorials)

Existing tutorials

  • Fundamentals of WebXR (to proof read to and get rid of "draft" banner)
  • WebXR application lifecycle (to complete)
  • Starting up and shutting down a WebXR Session (to proofread)
  • Geometry and reference spaces in WebXR (to proofread)
  • Spaces and reference spaces: Spatial tracking (to proofread, to complete, to remove draft banner)
  • Rendering and the WebXR frame animation callback (to proofread)
  • Viewpoints and viewers: Simulating cameras (to proofread)
  • Lighting a WebXR setting (to proofread and possible expand for Lighting Estimation module)
  • Using bounded reference spaces (to be completed, to proofread, to remove draft banner)
  • Movement, orientation, and motion (to proofread)
  • Targeting and Hit detection (to be completed, talk about Hit Testing Module)
  • WebXR performance guide (to be completed)
    • Talk about foveate rendering (rendering more cheaply at lower resolution in the periphery of the view), refresh rates (there's some documentation here but I don't think it covers requesting low and high refresh rates, the refresh rate API, and what to do in practice to monitor and manage refresh rate), multiview.
  • WebXR permissions and security (to complete; MDN still needs to document the Permission-Policy header, still documents this as Feature-Policy -> side project; talk about secure origin requirement)

New tutorials to write

  • Using WebXR input profiles. Cover Hands Input profile
  • Gamecontroller (Gamepad API) in WebXR
  • WebXR Layers / Playing video in a 3D environment
  • First person observer / secondary views (#7153 (comment)). Maybe integrate this aspect into the "Viewports and viewers" article?)
  • Positional audio in a 3D environment (not integrated into WebXR, address this topic later, remove from landing page)

item.title: [webgl2] Issue with "WebGL2RenderingContext.getBufferSubData()": Argument 3 does not implement interface ArrayBufferView
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL2RenderingContext/getBufferSubData

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The dstData argument of type ArrayBuffer doesn't work and results in this error:

Uncaught TypeError: WebGL2RenderingContext.getBufferSubData: Argument 3 does not implement interface ArrayBufferView.

Specific section or headline?

Parameters and Examples

What did you expect to see?

Data from the buffer

Did you test this? If so, how?

Example code:

let canvas = document.createElement("canvas");
let gl = canvas.getContext("webgl2");
let position_buffer = gl.createBuffer();
gl.bindBuffer(gl.ARRAY_BUFFER, position_buffer);
let positions = [
    -1.0, 1.0, 0.0,
    1.0, 1.0, 0.0,
    -1.0, -1.0, 0.0,
    1.0, -1.0, 0.0,
    1.0, 1.0, 0.0,
    -1.0, -1.0, 0.0
];
gl.bufferData(gl.ARRAY_BUFFER, new Float32Array(positions), gl.STATIC_DRAW);

let arrBuffer = new ArrayBuffer(positions.length * Float32Array.BYTES_PER_ELEMENT);
gl.getBufferSubData(gl.ARRAY_BUFFER, 0, arrBuffer);

item.title: [webgl2] Issue with "WebGL2RenderingContext.getBufferSubData()": Example is not working.
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL2RenderingContext/getBufferSubData

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The Examples section is wrong, this is not how this method is used.

Specific section or headline?

This example will throw because dstData must be an ArrayBufferView, it can't be a bare ArrayBuffer.
But even though I'm not an expert myself in the subject matter, it seems the whole example isn't a good example of how this method should be used.

What did you expect to see?

A real good example of how and when to use this method. It seems https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL_API/WebGL_best_practices#non-blocking_async_data_downloadreadback has a better (at least working) example, but maybe it does more than required? I can't really judge that.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I read the specs and tested in both Firefox and Chrome.

count

But "elements" isn't clear. If I am trying to draw a single gl.TRIANGLE, is it expecting that argument to be 1 (if elements means triangles) or 3 (if elements means indices)?

Specific section or headline?

count

What did you expect to see?

More precise wording to understand what the function is expecting

Did you test this? If so, how?

item.title: [webgl1, webgl2] https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/bindFramebuffer
item.content:encoded:
Request type

  • Please close this issue, I accidentally submitted it without adding any details
  • New documentation
  • Correction or update

Details

The documentation page for gl.bindFramebuffer (here) does not make it clear that in order to bind the default framebuffer (to render to the screen), you would do gl.bindFramebuffer(gl.FRAMEBUFFER, null). This is an important use case of this function, and it should be documented.
